awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Field Demonstration of Ship Hull Inspection with a Fleet of Unmanned Underwater Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to protect marine ecosystems against invasive species and to help the shipping industry reduce its greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Marine invasive species are considered to be one of the greatest threats to marine and coastal biodiversity worldwide, second only to habitat loss. Keeping the oceans healthy is essential to preserve the employment, development and growth of the ocean economy. This is particularly relevant in the United States, where the marine economy contributes nearly $400 billion to the nation's gross domestic product with 40 percent of the population living in coastal counties. One of the main vectors for the transfer of marine invasive species is the biofouling on ship hulls, described as the undesirable accumulation of microorganisms, plants, algae and animals on the submerged hull. A second impact of biofouling is to increase the drag forces on the hull, resulting in an increase of the ship's fuel consumption and GHG emissions in the atmosphere. This project advances a system for in-water inspection of ship hulls with a fleet of Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs). The automated underwater inspection system will provide maritime stakeholders with biofouling data to optimize hull cleaning schedules, validate compliance with regulations, thereby improving ship performance and ecosystem health. 

This project develops a system leveraging a UUV fleet that forms an arch operated from a vessel (e.g. power boat, crew vessel) located at one of the arch's extremities. It can inspect hulls as ships enter or leave ports without having to be immobilized. The UUVs exchange data wirelessly between each other and with the surface, enabling autonomous coordinate inspections without tethers but under human supervision. An advanced positioning system and control scheme will be implemented to enable accurate localization without GPS and precise operation in the vicinity of the hull. This project will conduct in-water experiments to validate the performance of the positioning system and control scheme. The outcome of the project will be a proof-of-concept where a fleet of two UUVs inspect the hull of a vessel, demonstrating that the inspection system is fast, practical and repeatable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During Phase I project, Berkeley Marine Robotics (BMR) built its first prototype for fast automated inspection of ships hulls biofouling with a swarm of Unmanned Underwater Vehicles (UUVs). While the team is still working towards a proof of concept of the prototype with all systems integrated, several technical achievements have significantly advanced the technology readiness of the invention. In addition, the beat-the-odds bootcamp and commercialization planning of the Phase I award enabled the team to greatly advance the commercialization of the innovation by better understanding its potential customers and the required commercial efforts to pursue this opportunity.  

 

Over the course of the project, the technology has progressed from a TRL 2-3 to a TRL 4-5 as all technical systems have been validated either in laboratory or during field tests. The technical achievements are listed below:

  • Control of an UUV with hull following capabilities.
  • Field demonstration of a boat hull inspection with a team of UUVs.
  • Design and Fabrication of 4 laser terminal prototypes for Free-Space Optical (FSO) communication.
  • Development of a Pointing, Acquisition and Tracking (PAT) algorithm for FSO communication.
  • Demonstration of PAT capabilities of the laser terminals in laboratory.
  • Demonstration of FSO communication capabilities of the laser terminals in laboratory.
  • Development and Numerical simulation of coordinated control of UUVs (swarm control) with hull following capabilities.
  • Fabrication of the swarm prototype: assembly of 2 UUVs and integration of the laser terminals in the UUVs, fabrication of the launching frame with locks and integration of laser terminal connected to the control station in the frame.
  • Test of of experimental set-up (transportation, launch, recovery, ...) with commercial diving companies in Long Beach, CA paving the way for further field tests of our prototype and eventually a field demonstration of ship hull inspection with all systems integrated.

 

Bootcamp has been an opportunity to do a deep dive in hull management practices for ships and coatings performance and validated the hull management workflow and our go-to-market strategy. We are the only underwater data company that makes fast automated underwater inspections for ships managers who want to manage hull performance during a time of increasing environmental regulation. Our solution enables optimal cleaning with hull performance analysis and can unlock 10% savings in GHG emissions and fuel consumption.

 

The results of the project have been presented by PI A. Immas at a TMA BlueTech Global Connect webinar and at a major biofouling R&D forum at the International Maritime Organization headquarter. Moving forward, the key steps of the technology development are to demonstrate the laser terminals PAT and FSO capabilities underwater and to test the prototype with all systems integrated. We will go through several testing cycles to improve the performance of the systems that will eventually lead to a proof of concept of the final prototype that we plan to accomplish in S1 2023.
